Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2014 10:05PM susan3 wrote: hello ladies..I am new to this thread. Just wanted to pop . I had my recurrence almost 3 yrs ago now. Many many nodes in neck, clavicle, alongside  neck by jugular , lung, rib, spine..think that's where Waldo has been showing up. I stay on chemos for about 4 months then we have to change cause Waldo starts to move around again...always need to find him. Can't to targeted treatment anymore cause I became hormone refractory . Waldo eats up those treatments like food and spreads even faster. So general chemo for me. This last one I started December 13 th, havelan.....and I am still on it. And with good reports. The only node detectable is one in my jawline on left side, but it is smaller than it was in December.  Best news I have had in 3 years. Maybe this one will,work for a nice long time. Se are very very doable. I have been having a blast since February, and will continue to do so :) , for as long as I can! Hope we can all get on something that gives us great relief for quit a fee months so we can live fully and maybe for a moment, maybe, just forget we have this......hugs to all

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2012 04:37AM susan3 wrote: i have a power port. 2 week before use, my doc said. me too, never wanted it, still dont, but much easier. heres what i didnt know, when i went in for pet scan, they didnt have a person who was trained in ports..who knew! so they had to use the vien. they told me i needed to go to the hospitol i usually go to, then the other hospitol for tests, then back to first hospitol for port removal. so dont just set up your tests, make sure they will have a person who is qua;ified to access your port at you appt time to. i know, yo r thinking, where the heck do you live...belive or not CHICAGO..go figure. we just learn as we go. dont loose your sense of humor:). the surgery itself for me was easy, 15 min surgery, one hour of antibiotics. i have heard some take longer but mine was good. need to mark your body, bra, seatbelt etc. i was told to mark my left side, when i got there hey did surgery on the right, again,who knew!  but when they draw blood, piece of cake. good luck, hope this helped

Posts.Title: Expected Life SPAMgirl jocanuck1951

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2012 05:50PM susan3 wrote: when mine came back after 10 1/2 years the surgeon told me i had 2 years. my onc said he had lots of tricks in his bag and he will tell me when we r close cause he knows i would like to know that. i have gone through 4 dif meds treatments in 1 1/2 years and he says he still has 4 more on his shelf. maybe one of them will last a bit longer. no one knows. but i cant get that ringing out of my ears of the 2 yrs. and it was said so matter of factly. i feel great, considering, still working, still exercising, and planning daughters wedding. don't think the surgeon was right. and i don't think she should have said anything. hang in there. there r some AMAZING stories out there. maybe we will all have some amazing stories, hugs to all
Posts.Title: Expected Life SPAMgirl jocanuck1951

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2012 04:23PM susan3 wrote: my back is getting better, thanks Kathy.  i don't understand the "time lines" either. i have no idea if my "definition" at the bottom is how it should be written either..lol when mine came back it was a node under my arm, and within a month there were over 40 nodes and distant locations. it is not operable at this point. i don't hear of a lot of people on these forums with lots of node involvement that cant be surgically removed. mine are tied up in lots of neck muscles and jugular vein. they wouldn't b able to get clear margins and don't want to take a chance of cutting through the cancer. so we are trying to maintain through treatment. but i seem to b able to last about 3 months and then they have to change it up. and right now there are only so many out there. i am sure they can test how aggressive it is, and that is what the surgeon made her decision on. bottom line is, no one knows. just put one foot in front o the other. been hard for me lately. getting ready for my daughters wedding is sooo much fun, but thinking i wont be her for her during her married life and prob wont see grandchildren is a bit overwhelming at times..oh well, sorry for going on an on. spending too much time with ice on my back and to much time in my head these days. thanks for listening. hugs to all

Posts.Content: May 26, 2016 04:54AM susan3 wrote: when I first got dx 15 years ago, I got in the tub...that where I pour out my soul, and just balled. Claire was in 5 th grade. And as we all know to well here, the horrible feeling of leaving them. During my crying bout, I was not really praying to God, wY more like yelling, but a confused yelling. You see Dan and I couldn't conceive, so we went through a doner program. My doner was a doc, first generation spainard. And Claire knows. So when this happened, the cancer, I couldn't wrap my mind around allowing a baby, than taking the mom away. During my crying I suddenly got very calm, and realized, I have control over my heart and soul....that is really it. No more no less. And my soul and heart belongs to God and Jesus, I know people find peace in different beliefs, all good, but that sense of peace has held me up through all of this. I hope everyone can find their peace. I know Rosie has, not to say there aren't very difficult days, there will always be those on this side of heaven. But I have found so much beauty in the fire too. Those days I cherish so close to my heart.. Love you my friends :)

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2015 02:24PM susan3 wrote: I strongly agree with mri. I was 38 when I had a call back for 6 month check. Cancer grows so they are looking to see if it got bigger over 6 months. This actually went on till I was 40. Went to breast surgeons...the whole nine yards, everyone said I was ok, spot never grew, no worries. Mom also had bc. It was a tumor after all, never grew for the mam to detect. Mri would have shown it. 2001 bilateral was done. Unfortunately it did get into nodes. I to. Had other things that bothered me. Needless to say, I am with a different team. You have to be your own advocate. You seem to know your body well. push for what you need. Good luck :

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2017 10:13PM susan3 wrote: happy I found you gals:). Have fallen off my biking, runs, and swimming over the last three years. Real bad this summer. Had to get off my road bike cause I couldn't breath. Lot of trouble oxygenating. Had my lungs and heart throughly checked out, all is ok. So I bought a treadmill, my thinking is it's prob easier to exercise in a controlled climate. Up to a mile and a half. Far cry from my marathons, but I will be happy with 5 miles. I hike with a great group, but I so miss my running and fast biking. Hopefully this summer the bike won't be a problem. Gotta stay motivated even though it's such a struggle to breathe:). It is much much better indoors

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2016 08:04AM susan3 wrote: Rosie, I have been on both taxol and taxotere, don't know if that means things I have been on would be on the table for you. With my cancer, each chemo lasts 4 months than cancer wins. Right now, I should have been through all treatment options and waiting to die from the cancer. 18 months ago, I was put on , I thin, the first breast cancer drug they ever came out with. The newer nurses have never heard of it. CMF...fu5. That is what I have been on for 18 months! Doc has nooooo idea why it's working for so long, but we are happy campers. Maybe that is an option for you. An oldie but a goodie. Doc just pulled it out of his hat cause we are running out of options, and why not give it a try. Good luck, love and prayers Rosie.

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2012 06:16AM susan3 wrote: i am sad to have lost my best friend for now. i hope she returns to my life. she was my go to person for humor. no matter how bad my day was, it took her just a few words to crack me up and all was better. she just had both breast removed from cancer a couple months ago. she has shut me out. never on purpose, she is a wonderful person, she was with me 12 years ago when this started. early detection no big deal, i was to be fine. shocked the docs when it came back along with the rest of us. she got told the same, caught early no biggy, we got it. how could i not be her worst nightmare right now!!! i feel so bad for  her, hopefully she will someday b able to be around me without fear, she helped me through soooo much, and right now my mere existence must terrify her. it takes us all a while to wrap our minds around what we are dealing with, i pray she is able to walk through the fire and come out the other side...thanks or listening

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2012 11:58AM susan3 wrote: pearlady1, i am on my 3rd package. a/a . i am on the 10 ml still. my doc said this  week i am only one of 2 of his patients able to stay on it and we both run bike and juice. have no idea if that makes a differene. all our bodies are so different. a did well on xeloda to. bad feet, but not as bad as most, but the xeloda only worked for 3 months. i seem to tolerate meds well but the cancer outsmarts them, thats were my trouble is. i take one tramadol a day to for the back spams and that tales care of that. now starting with bump irations on my head but they are not so bothersome. day to day, tuff stuff for our bodies to handle. keep me posted. hang in there susan

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2016 03:09PM susan3 wrote: ohhhh Rosie, some people....EGR...extra grace required ...to bad there are so many of them. I will tell you a nice story to revive your heart. Today I was suppose to do a cancer walk. Got a few friends to sign up with me. I couldn't go today cause I am not at home in Chicago . In Michigan helping my daughter out. ( new baby). The walk was at soldier field. Over an hour away from where I live. One of my friends drove there to represent me, with her 2 kids...10 and 7 years old to do the walk. Took a long time with the kids but she was determined to represent me. Made my heart swell. There are a lot of great people out there too :) And Rosie, you are one of them :)
Posts.Title: Rosevalley - this is for you! Zillsnot4me Kandy

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2015 07:26PM susan3 wrote: good luck and best wishes to you. I had ac in 2001. Heart was fine, and I don't remember a lot of issues. Was tired, but prob cause I was still working full time. Hate to tell you this, but the taxol, taxotere , those drug lines I think are the yuckiest. At least for me that was the case. You will get through them all.....they all affect something different. I would think they would be more similar, but they aren't . And that is actually good, I think, cause you wouldn't want them all to be hurting the same things in your body, so nice they figured out how to rotate the side effects. Lol. Hang in ther
Posts.Title: Chemo scares me more than the disease AnewBeginning lcm123

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2015 08:56AM susan3 wrote: I do better just listening I pick up more. We are all so different in that way. For me, there is acquiring to much info , that will lead me down the obsession path. I really like my doc which helps, and in my case, the knowledge I have accumulated is because of the years and years I have been going through this. This is going to be a bad analogy, so I apologize in advance..haha....but for me ( the knowledge part) I learned as I went along. Stored the info in my head that people gave me, but we are all so diff, just like our kids, and eventually you see the bigger picture and understand what you body Is going through, and what makes yours unique in comparison to others. God bless and enjoy every moment you can hug your arms around :)
Posts.Title: Chemo scares me more than the disease AnewBeginning lcm123

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2012 01:00AM susan3 wrote: believe it or not, i wanted cleaning help..dont laugh. i knew i would be mad if i watched my daughter and hubby doing everything. so when all my friends and church asked what they could do , i told them i wanted cleaning help. they collected money for 6 months of help. it was great. i had a bi-lateral free tram. so my lower stomach muscle and fat are now my boobs. took awhile to re-coop. only thing i hated were the drains. i hear now the have cammies with pockets in them so you drains have a place to be. didnt have that 12 years ago. they have come a long way with comfort. hang in there' hugs to you girls
Posts.Title: bi-lateral in 2 weeks lost in sea of posts of what I need ConnieGreene exbrnxgrl

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2012 12:11AM susan3 wrote: so far i have been able to take full 10ml every day with aromisen. i found the first 12 hours the worst so now i take it at night and an hour later a take a sleeping pill, and i am doing well considering what this drug can do, also still walking or running, whatever my body feels like. and yes i also stay on couch for one full day. seems to help make it through the rest of the week. hope that helps some. i juice veggies for energy

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2012 04:00PM susan3 wrote: i exercise till i crash then i recover and do it again, some days i can walk 5 miles others its around the block. i used to be a runner so i did come at this from a different point. i feel good chugging along cause i feel i am some what in control of that. i don't get mad anymore when i cant go far, but when i am feeling good and can go out for a long walk, it is sooooo wonderful, makes me remember my running days, and it feel so good. hopefully i will be able to do it in spurts for a long time :)
Posts.Title: Fatigue from chemo SE's compounded by inactivity? jcb51 soleil505

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2012 11:14AM susan3 wrote: i have bee n on chemo and hormone therapy. right now hormone therapy  afinitor and aromisen. hormone therapy scares me to death. my cancer is hormone refractory (no idea if i spelled that right), it means the hormones treatment that use to kill my cancer cells for 8 years, now feed them and make them grow at an incredibly fast rate. so that is why the afinitor in combo with hormone drugs. but when the afinitor stops working, are we going to catch it asap so it doesn't spread anymore??? ahhhhhhh i have a great onc, but i am going for another opinion this tues and flying out to California to see my old doc and his team in a couple of weeks. need to be as pro active as possible. hang in there girls.

Posts.Title: Will I die from MBC? diana50 Heidihill

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2012 04:49PM susan3 wrote: havent had the big "D" with this one. i have headaches all the time. and yes i have ben on femara, tomixefin first 5 yrs, and then femara, then it came back. did faslodex, but i was allergic to it, so they had me on lots of allergy meds and i 2 months it spread to a lot of lymph nodes, so it didnt work for me. then xeloda, that was fantastic, 48 hours all nodes normal size, and we are talking well over 30 of them. i stopped counting at some point..lol but that only lasted 3 months, but at least we were at a better starting point. then came chemo, forgot name, just released again after being off market for a long while, when a/a became available we switched to that. so i still have that other chemo on the table and i tink 3 or  more. and they are always coming up with new stuff. yeah research!!!!  hugs to all susan

Posts.Content: May 1, 2014 01:24AM susan3 wrote: sorry to hear. Hugs to you. My forever has been 2 1/2 years so far. I do whatever the chemos let me do. I am back to playing tennis on the one I am on now. Haven't been able to do that in a long while. What keeps me going is finding that thing I can do so I don't think to much about the thing I have. Diversional tactics are my best friend. Hang in there
Posts.Title: "chemo forever" Jaxzgirl Kaelia

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2012 09:47PM susan3 wrote: my brother is good. asks lots of questions and worries. now here's a loop i will throw at you guys, its my mother. She has called me weak, and so many other things much meaner. Its not just the guys who don't know how to act!! I have decided to take the high road. It has become easier cause i have great friends that I often text AHHHHHHHHH and they know what that means. blainejennifer and everyone else, just let it out her so we can move passed it as best as possible. some things can never be explained. My hubby and daughter are great, and i hold tightly on to them:) good luck everyone...and a good cry is cleansing
Posts.Title: How to Deal with Uncommunicative Family blainejennifer LauraOntario

Posts.Title: ned susan3 bhd1

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2012 01:24PM susan3 wrote: positive nodes found last year. the different treatments i have been on have kept the cancer in the nodes. some have shrunk. on the new meds afinitor. just started 29 days ago. we will see if they help. everything they hav e put me on this time around has worked immediately, but the cancer seems stronger right now. can only get 1 to 5 months out of each treatment. hoping one lasts a bit longer :)  thanks for the info. found this site at 2 am yesterday.  love it. thank you all !!!!;0 i eel great that i ahv last 11 years. tamoxifen and famera really did the trick for a long time. i feel the cancer has been plotting since and got real smart. we just need to outsmart it again
